Foreword
The Rinaldi Guard possess a long history within Triskellian and Calabria. We do not only defend the House and her members, but her honor and the citizens of Triskellian. We are the Rinaldi's only military force. We are her army, and when war comes we step up to fight. Those who have the promise of skill and the courage and honor to serve the Don and House Rinaldi will always be welcome to join.
Chapter I: Ranks

Chapter I: Ranks
- Recruit: This is the lowest rank a guard can have. All recruits are initially given the base uniform, House Cloak, and a weapon (if needed) and will be assessed over the following week to see if they are fit for the guard. If they are deemed fit, they will be asked to take the oath to become an official guard and will be issued a dress uniform.
- Guard: Will be issued base uniform and dress uniform as well as a purple sash for the dress uniform (see uniforms for more information). Those of this rank have passed the recruit period and have officially sworn their loyalty to the House.
- Sergeant: Bronze trimmed gambeson and bronze sash (see uniforms for more information). Along with basic duties of a guard, Sergeants will be responsible for recruiting and mentoring new members as well as the most senior Sergeant taking command of the guard if the Captain and the lieutenants are absent from the city.
- Lieutenant: Silver trimmed gambeson and silver sash(see uniforms for more information). Lieutenants of the Guard take charge of the Guard should the Captain be absent for any reason (senior most lieutenant), when the Captain is active the Lieutenant has the duty of keeping an eye on the Sergeants.
- Captain: Gold trimmed gambeson and gold sash (see uniforms for more information). The Captain is in charge of the entire Guard. It is the Captain's responsibility to see that Guard continues to prosper and serve the House as it should.

Chapter II: Duties

Chapter II: Duties
These duties are expected to be performed by all members of the Rinaldi Guard, they are:
- Protect members of the Rinaldi: The purpose of the Guard is to protect members of the Rinaldi and the Rinaldi's interests. If a person or building is being harrassed or harmed, it is our job to step in and handle the situation. We do not have the authority to arrest or fine anyone and we should not interfere in matters that do not involve the Rinaldi directly. That is what the Constabulary is for. If someone (with honor) is insulting the Rinaldi, we can ask for an apology. If they do not give an apology, we can challenge them to a duel. If they choose not to accept, they will be labeled a coward and it is assumed that they are taking back their offensive words. (See rules on dueling for more information). Avoid arguing to make yourself sound right. The only time this is remotely acceptable is if you are defending the honor of the House or a member of the House, but you should always be the better person and avoid arguments or allowing yourself to be provoked into a negative reaction. We represent the House even moreso than most other House members as we are seen in Oldtown, Newtown, and Docktown. You are expected to represent the House well.
- Patrol daily: Upon being recruited, guards will be assigned an area in the city to patrol daily (OOC: This can be bluebooked, although for the sake of RP do you should do the patrol sometimes).
- Write weekly reports: Guards are to write reports of their observations. If a week has gone by without any notable events, that still needs to be reported.
- Train: All members should find training outside the House even though there is weekly training sessions.
-Officer Training: All members sergeant and under are expected to attend officer training, if you cannot be sure to let a higher ranking member (preferrably the Captain) know. Lieutenants are not required to attend, but it is recommended for the sake of remembering what was taught.
- Attend meetings: It is unreasonable to expect all members to attend all meetings but attempts should be made. If a member is unable to attend a meeting, an officer (meaning sergeants and lieutenants) or Captain should be contacted and told such.

Chapter III: Conduct

Chapter III: Conduct
In addition to the duties listed on the previous chapter, all guards are expected to conduct themselves as men and women of civil nature. While we understand that those you will often interact with have no interest in civility or etiquette, guards are expected to rise above the fray and be the better man. Expected behavior includes, but is not limited to:
- Respect for Nobility: Whether of the Great House of Rinaldi, another Great House or even perhaps a Minor House, all members of the nobility are to be extended courtesy and respect at all times. They are your betters and you will acknowledge that through your actions. Bow to known nobility. Address them according to their social rank (when in doubt, "my lord/lady" is always safe). If they require assistance of any sort, render it, even if it means performing a menial task you might otherwise consider beneath you. Offer escort through dangerous areas. As you continue to conduct yourself in a matter befitting a member of genteel society, you will earn the respect of your betters. Continued failure to respect nobility may result in a dishonorable discharge.
- Public Behavior: Do not engage in frivolous and untoward activities. Always present yourself as a respectable member of society. To be a Rinaldi Guard does not mean that you must only impress your superiors and comrades. You are the face of the Rinaldi wherever you go. If your reputation is tarnished, the reputation of the Guard and the House is tarnished in turn. Even when in the company of other freedmen act with grace and honor. Do not engage in public rowdiness. Do not drink to excess. Do not fraternize with members of the same or opposite sex in such a way that others may speak ill of you. Continued failure to act befitting of the Guard may result in a dishonorable discharge.
- Interaction with Other Members of the Guard: One cannot enter a martial organization and expect to not adhere to a chain of command. Explained elsewhere, this chain is vital to the functioning of the Guard and it is built upon respect. To this end, you will always greet a superior with a salute, much as a jousting knight will raise his visor to salute his opponent. Superiors will be addressed by their rank and never by their given name alone. Same ranking members should also be greeted with a salute, and will be addressed as "Miss" or "Mister" unless they say otherwise. Romantic relationships with fellow guards is highly frowned upon, such can lead to distractions from duty. Failure to follow chain of command WILL result in a dishonorable discharge.

Chapter IV: Uniforms and Off Duty Wear

Chapter IV: Uniforms and Off duty wear
Base uniform:
-A pearly white cotton shirt/blouse
-A pair of midnight black wool pants
-A pair of midnight black leather infantry boots
-A pair of midnight black leather swordsman gloves
-A midnight black leather double wrap belt
-A lavender grey damask gambeson embroidered with the Rinaldi symbol
Base uniforms are to be worn when on duty and when on the battlefield.
Dress uniform:
-A pearly white ruffled silk shirt/blouse
-A pair of pearly wool pants
-A pair of midnight black leather infantry boots
-A pair of midnight black leather swordsman gloves
-A midnight black leather double wrap belt
-A lavender grey damask sleeveless doublet.
-A lavender grey damask cavalier hat
-House Cloak or Ring
-Rank sash
Dress uniforms will only ever be worn to formal occassions, be sure to remove your hat upon arrival.
Rank accessories:
Gambeson trimmings:
Recruit and Guard: None
Sergeant: Bronze trimming
Lieutenant: Silver Trimming
Captain: Gold trimming
Sashes (for dress uniforms only)
Recruit: Recruits are not issued dress uniforms
Guard: Purple sash
Sergeant: Bronze sash
Lieutenant: Silver sash
Captain: Gold sash.
Off duty wear must contain either your House Cloak or House Ring.

Chapter V: Officer Training

Chapter V: Officer Training
Officer training will be classes every two weeks about command, conduct, military tactics, and leadership. It is mandatory for all Guards sergeants and lower. Lieutenants may attend, but it will not be mandatory for them, however, it is recommended they attend if only to refresh their memories on the subjects taught. The class will be taught by the captain or the most senior officer. Once a guard has gone through all five topics they will be eligible for lieutenancy and will no longer be required to attend but it will be recommended again if only to refresh yourself on the topics.

Chapter VI: Guard Philosophy

Chapter VI: Guard Philosophy
We all should strive to adopt these values into our lifestyles. Although we will never reach perfection, we will never stop working toward it.
- Loyalty: Bear true faith and allegiance to the House Rinaldi, Triskellian's Laws, The Guard, and other soldiers. Be loyal to the nation and its heritage.
- Duty: Fulfill your obligations. Accept responsibility for your own actions and those entrusted to your care. Find opportunities to improve oneself for the good of the group.
- Respect: How we consider others reflects upon each of us, both personally and as a professional organization.
- Selfless Service: Put the welfare of the Guard, the House Rinaldi, and your subordinates before your own. Selfless service leads to organizational teamwork and encompasses discipline, self-control and faith in the system.
- Honor: Live up to the Rinaldi Guard Values.
- Integrity: Do what is right, legally and morally. Be willing to do what is right even when no one is looking. It is our 'moral compass" an inner voice.
- Personal Courage: Our ability to face fear, danger, or adversity, both physical and moral courage.
- As Written by Baron Marcus di Rinaldi
